author: mazhar10
body:
Standalone managed service accounts are defined at [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/identity-protection/access-control/service-accounts](url)

This includes accounts that an app pool on IIS runs under by default.
If you have PS code that calls `ConverTo-SecureString`, you will see that this cmdlet always returns back an empty string. Running under other accounts, even localsystem etc., makes this cmdlet work fine.

In my case, after wasting hours in debugging, I set my app pool to run under localsystem instead of the default standalone managed account (which has the same name as the app pool itself), and everything started working fine.

comments.author: JAK1047
comments.body:
For my automation at my work I exclusively use gMSAs to run all my Powershell tasks. Every now and then though you do need the script to call an actual account (for example connecting to VMWare), so in these situations I've always made the gMSA use ConvertTo-SecureString and ConvertFrom-SecureString to then saved the encrypted value in a location like an Azure Key Vault. Works fine and the result hash can only be decrypted by the gMSA that ran it on the server that ran it which leads me to think that's using DPAPI. Quick example of how I make my various gMSAs encrypt and save the password for later use since you can't directly run Powershell using them without a task.

```
$Command = @'
    $User = $(([Security.Principal.WindowsIdentity]::GetCurrent()).Name.Replace("$ENV:USERDOMAIN\",'') -replace '\$')
    #Connect to AZ to add password to Key Vault    
    Connect-AzAccount -Identity

    $Password = 'PasswordGoesHere'
    #Convert to secure string for ConvertFrom-SecureString to take advantage of DPAPI
    $SecurePassword = ConvertTo-SecureString -String $Password -AsPlainText -Force
    #Conversion
    $EncryptedPassword = ConvertFrom-SecureString -SecureString $SecurePassword
    #Convert hash back to a secure string because Set-AzKeyVaultSecret won't take a regular string
    $EncryptedSecurePassword = ConvertTo-SecureString -String $EncryptedPassword -AsPlainText -Force
    #Add to vault
    Set-AzKeyVaultSecret -VaultName 'Automation' -Name "Admin-$User" -SecretValue $EncryptedSecurePassword
'@

#Make a PS1 with the above script
$Command | Out-File -FilePath C:\Update.ps1

#Generate new task action
$Action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute 'Pwsh.exe' -Argument '-File C:\Update.ps1'

$GMSAArray = 'PKIGMSA$',     
'WebGMSA$',     
'ADGMSA$',      
'StreemGMSA$',    
'O365GMSA$',    
'ExchangeGMSA$',
'MiscGMSA$',    
'AzureGMSA$',     
'CitrixGMSA$'  

#For all my gMSAs create the task and run it
Get-ADObject -ldapfilter '(&(name=*GMSA*))' -SearchBase 'OU=OURGMSA,OU=GMSA,DC=contoso,DC=com' -Properties SamAccountName | ForEach-Object -Process {
    If ($_.SamAccountName -in $GMSAArray) {
        $Principal = New-ScheduledTaskPrincipal -UserID Contoso\$($_.SamAccountName) -LogonType Password

        $null = Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'Update GMSA' -Action $Action -Principal $Principal
        $null = Start-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'Update GMSA' 
        While ((Get-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'Update GMSA').State -ne 'Ready') { Start-Sleep -Seconds 1 }
        Unregister-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'Update GMSA' -Confirm:$False
  
        "Updating $($_.SamAccountName)"
    }
}

Remove-Item -Path C:\Update.ps1 -Force
```

Been working fine for me in both Powershell 5.1 and Pwsh 7.1. Does DPAPI work fine with a gMSA but not a MSA?

comments.author: mazhar10
comments.body:
My testing was all under MSA, and not gMSA.
From what I understand, ConvertTo-SecureString uses DPAPI. Here is what I think PS should do:
1) if DPAPI is available, then invoke, return back whatever DPAPI returns, be it success or error etc.
2) if DPAPI is not available, then return back an error message.
This will take care of JAK's and my use cases, The issue I see if that (by design or not), PS is returning a success with an empty string when DPAPI is NOT available - this, to me, is wrong, as the invoker would not know what happened.

comments.author: JustinGrote
comments.body:
Haven't seen anything specific to MSA or gMSA, but the issue as described here is ConvertTo-SecureString returning a null ('silently failing') rather than the expected "encrypted" string. Nothing about this is secretmanagement specific unless I"m missing something.

In a secretmanagement extension vault you occasionally convert plaintext from the "vault" to a securestring, so checks can be added there and throw errors, that will be extension vault specific however, because it's perfectly valid to return a null secret in some circumstances.

@iSazonov I don't think it's unreasonable to add a check to ConvertTo-SecureString if DPAPI is available, or if content *was* provided to convertto-securestring but it returned a null result for whatever reason, to emit a non-terminating error (or even warning). This might be considered a breaking change however because of implementations that may be "working" due to this silently failing that would now "break" even though they probably should have broken to begin with.

That said, it's also equally reasonable to add the check in your own code @mazhar10 if it's affecting you.
```powershell
$mysecret = 'mytest' | ConvertTo-SecureString -asplaintext -force

if ($null -eq $mysecret) {throw 'Unable to convert to SecureString. DPAPI may not be available on this platform or under this specific account'}
```
